You know what you're going to get with a Malcolm Gladwell book - some interesting case studies, a few fascinating tidbits that will undoubtedly be useful in dinner party conversation, and an all-around well-written, engaging book. Outliers is no exception.There are some great case studies (especially in the second half of the book--I found the anecdotes on the increased likelihood of plane crashes due to varying methods of communication across culture especially fascinating) and it's chock full of interesting information, but I found the main point of the book pretty depressing. That main point was essentially it's all well and good to work hard and be a self-made man, but the fact of the matter is, any successful person needs a whole lotta luck. Be it your birthdate, your insanely wealthy parents, or even anti-semitism, no one succeeds without being in the right place at the right time. And call me a sap, but that just depresses the hell out of me.I suppose on some level everyone knows that no one succeeds without luck. One of my favorite sports quotes is from Mark Cuban, owner of the Dallas Mavericks and multi-billionaire, who created and developed an internet streaming radio company that, during the dot-com boom, was sold to Yahoo for just under $6 billion. Shaquille O'Neal, at the time the best basketball player in the world, was talking about Cuban and said that Cuban wasn't a brilliant businessman, but was really "just lucky." Cuban, in turn, scoffed at the mark and said something to the effect of, "Yeah, I just got lucky. But Shaq being 7'1" 330 pounds, that was planned." And I love that quote because it perfectly sums up the point Gladwell is making in this book--they're both right.Cuban is an obviously talented entrepreneur, but he was lucky in that his company took off at the perfect time to catch the dotcom boom in the late 90s. At the same time, Cuban did come up with an innovative idea, and the company he sold to Yahoo is still flourishing today, to say nothing of the technology he helped to pioneer with that company. So while it's not unfair to say he was lucky, you can see where a very intelligent innovator such as Cuban might scoff at such talk. And it's true that Shaq was lucky enough to win the genetic lottery, but there are plenty of extremely large men without his talent and competitiveness who never did anywhere near the things that O'Neal accomplished (just ask Clippers or Timberwolves fans about Michael Olowokandi).Gladwell's point is that it takes hard work, sacrifice, and all the other buzzwords you'll read about in the biographies of hugely successful people. But it also just takes dumb luck. This makes for a fascinating read, but it's ultimately not the most inspirational book you'll read this year.

This book changed my perspective on achievement and success. Gladwell posits that success depends not on extraordinary talent, but extraordinary opportunities. He makes a compelling case that there’s no such thing as a “self-made” man, but that we’re all products of our cultural legacy, community, and advantages available to us. I especially liked the recurring theme that successful people consistently work harder than their peers; their achievement is a function of their persistence, not their talent.The book is mostly stories and anecdotes, sprinkled throughout with statistics and analyses. Gladwell is a long-winded storyteller, and takes his time getting to the point. I lowered my rating of the book because of this. I was bored silly by the lengthy chapter on how airplane miscommunications and crashes can be attributed to cultural legacies regarding respect for authority and assertiveness. But, as a technologist, I liked the story of how Bill Gates’ unique opportunities to practice programming during his formative years led him to Microsoft fame and fortune.Gladwell sets out to prove that (to paraphrase), success arises from the steady accumulation of advantages; when and where you were born, what your parents did for a living, and the circumstances of your upbringing. Our lives are a web of advantages and disadvantages, whether deserved or undeserved. Successful people are those in the right place at the right time, who jump on the opportunities they have to work hard.Gladwell succinctly summarizes the book near the end, as follows:“Success follows a predictable course. It’s not the brightest who succeed. Nor is success simply the sum of the decisions and efforts we make on our own. It’s a gift; the successful are those who have been given opportunities, and who have had the strength and presence of mind to seize them.”I liked the point that as long as you have a base level of talent in an area, your success depends on practice. It takes about 10,000 hours of practice to attain expertise, which usually takes about 10 years. Also, the law of diminishing returns applies to intelligence; once you have enough, it ceases to provide an advantage.Gladwell provides interesting insight into such questions as why Asians excel at math, and why American schoolchildren lag academically. He says that Asian numbering systems (especially Chinese) are more intuitive than Western systems, and their historical cultural legacies of hard work give Asians advantage over Westerners. He also shows the detrimental effects of short school days and summer vacations on American schoolchildren, because they spend less time practicing skills and more time forgetting.

I really enjoyed learning about the research that Gladwell used in this book, and with Gladwell's particular story-telling. I was already familiar with some but not all of the research, and of course, I already believed that we are not all self-made but usually largely dependent on our environments. That said, there was something a cognitively dissonant about including the 10000-hour rule in a book about how the most successful are typically not all self-made.

I liked this book. The main premise made a lot of sense to me. I was particularly fascinated by the story of Christopher Langan, the man with the highest IQ in America and the rain of tough luck that stood in the way of his success. If a man so gifted has a hard time succeeding is there any hope for the rest of us. The purpose of this book is to dispel the ethos that those who succeed do so because they are more intelligent, intrepid, and work harder than the rest of us. While it's true successful people may possess these attributes, they do so often to no greater extent than people who fail miserably. Gladwell sets out to prove that success is the product of a combination of hard work and fortuitous circumstances that a hard working person has the foresight/dumb luck to benefit from. He begins the book with the striking example of how being born at a certain time of the year is a great benefit to a Canadian hockey player. It's shocking to realize that such dumb luck could so thoroughly alter the course of lives and yet inarguably it does! I did some independent research on this subject and found that Wayne Gretzky was born on January 26th, Bobby Orr was born March 20th, Mark Messier was born January 18th, Tyler Seguin was born January 31st, just to name a few. I'm sure I could find many more contemporary and historical examples whose birthdate fell within this lucky window of January to March. Gladwell tells the story of Bill Gates, perhaps the most successful person whoever lived if your measure of success is money. Gladwell outlines the series of circumstances that fell perfectly in place for Gates, circumstances entirely out of Gates control and that he had nothing to do in bringing about and from which he benefitted enormously. These circumstances intersected wholly with Gate's interest in computers and propelled him to success as much as the work he did. Gate's experience was just the opposite of Langan's. Gates himself admits that he was lucky, we must take him at his word.I recommend this book if for nothing else than its refreshingly different slant on what makes someone successful, especially in this day and age when a a man who with the help of a million dollar loan from his daddy and a desperately depressed New York real estate market became a multi-billionaire and the presumptive republican presidential nominee. I can see no other characteristics that define Donald Trump beyond naked aggression and bellicose boorishness. I believe he would not be who and where he is if it weren't for total dumb luck, although he would scream in your face that his success is entirely his own because he has the best words after all.

Outliers by Malcolm Gladwell (#116 in 2019)"Outliers" are people who are defined as being the best, brightest, and most successful people in this world. In this book, Malcolm Galdwell seeks to discover WHY these people meet success so well and WHAT makes them different from the rest of us. Have you ever walked away from reading a book and genuinely felt smarter? That's how I felt after finishing Outliers! I actually walked away with knowledge I didn't have before and have used this book as a talking point in various conversations since. Just when I thought November was done and that I was done with obsessively reading nonfiction... I picked up this book. What do I call this? A story? A study? An investigation? Whatever you define it as, Gladwell investigates what we all tend to wonder: what makes successful people so successful? What makes some athletes better than others? What makes geniuses so much smarter than the rest of us? He answers this question in a few different ways, and he does it using comparisons, anecdotes, and data from scientific studies. The answer boils down to a combination of being in the right place at the right time, having the right skills, having the right genetic makeup, and being presented with the right opportunity. Sounds simple, right? It is simple, but Gladwell provides the facts to back up this theory, and he uses anecdotes to provide real-world examples-- Essentially Malcolm Gladwell is teaching us in the same way that we, teachers, teach our students. There are a variety of chapters including those detailing: why certain athletes are more successful than others, how many hours it takes to become an expert, a study of ethnic advantages and disadvantages, how our language shapes our success, and why Asians are better at math. Personally, my favorite chapter was explaining how Asian students are better at math than American students. I, personally, have never been a mathematician, but the teacher in me was curious to uncover the differences in learning. Gladwell's explanation of the difference between these groups of math students makes so much sense once you read through it, but it's something I never would have thought of. Was this review sort of vague? Yes, and I'm sorry. I could have gone on and on about what I learned from this book, but I don't want to ruin the eye-opening details for anyone else. If you're looking for a fast read to get through before the end of 2019, one that is brilliantly interesting, CHOOSE. THIS. ONE. Four stars ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

After having read the entire book, I arrived at the final few pages, in which Gladwell summarizes his main thesis. It goes something (actually exactly) like this: "Their (successful people) success is not exceptional or mysterious. It is grounded in a web of advantages and inheritances, some deserved, some not, some earned, some just plain lucky-but all critical to making them who they are. The outlier, in the end, is not an outlier at all" (pg. 285)I can't help but feel that this is, in fact, common sense in the form of a scientifical statement. Doesn't everyone know that successful people don't quote on quote "make it" all by themselves? They obviously have, along their pathways, what he calls "advantages and inheritances", and what I like to call: opportunities. Also, I can't help but feel that his book is, to some degree, full of contradictions. For example, in the first chapter he talks about how in Canada, prospective hockey players are chosen to play in elite leagues based on their birthdates. If you are born later in the year, chances are, you won't be chosen because the cutoff date is somewhere around March. The children that are accepted are then trained professionally, and go on to become celebrity athletes, all because of the advantage of their birthdate. Ok; reasonable.But then he comes along in chapter five talking about how Joe Flom, a Jewish layer, was able to become supremely successful, BECAUSE of his "disadvantaged" background. What? So what's the point then? If you're saying in the first chapter that being born on a certain date puts you at an unfixable disadvantage, but then sometimes disadvantages can be the very reason for the success...what??? No wonder Gladwell comes to the same GENERALIZED solution (aka common sense) as anyone with enough wit can arrive at: sometimes you win, sometimes you don't. Hard work, opportunities and persistence matter. Similar examples of contradictions can be found throughout the book.Overall, the book was well written, with many thought provoking ideas, such as the 10 000 hours rule, the importance of having social net, the perpetuation of culture throughout generations, etc... but it's just not the best read, simply because the argument doesn't make sense. The evidence supporting each point is radically different for each chapter, the book lacks consistency, and the core idea can't really be applied in the real world.

Thoroughly enjoyed reading this book. Firstly, Gladwell tackles deep-seated misconceptions about the way we define success by digging deeper into the backgrounds of certain successful people. In doing so, he reaffirms the notion that no man is an island; there were many other sociological, economic and geographic factors (not to mention sheer luck) that played a critical part in realizing certain outcomes for individuals, communities or even nations.Most insightful to me was his chapter on Korean Airlines. He starts off by describing in great detail the extent of Korean Airlines’ flight crash woes. It has nothing to do with the plane or external factors. He then pins down the cause of these woes on the Korean culture. Through the hierarchy prevalent in the Korean language specifically, communication is made harder between pilots. This ambiguity in a cockpit is what caused multiple crashes.Only in realizing that this was the problem after years did Korean Airlines ensure that all their pilots were fluent in English and used it to communicate with one another in the cockpit.In his further analysis, he touches on a concept called the Power-Distance Index (PDI), which basically ranks the countries according to how much they value and respect authority. The higher a country’s PDI, the further the relations between the wielders of power and those under them. No surprises to find Korea at Number Two on that list.He even seeks to explain why Asians are better at Mathematics than their Western counterparts by examining the values created between the farmers of rice in China and other non-intensive crops such as corn in the West.

Malcolm Gladwell sure loves to tell stories. This book is about 95 % storytelling and 5 % argumentation. Nevertheless Gladwell wants to state four things:1) To be successful you've got to be lucky2) No one can become successful on his own3) Success takes many, many hours of work2) Cultural heritage has a more profound influence than you'd wishSo, there you go. You can skip reading the book, for you hardly need Gladwell's evidence, which is pure anecdotal, anyway, and which has a disturbingly flimsy scientific basis, to say the least. Gladwell makes the common error of substituting correlation with causation, especially when connecting rice growing to math solving. He fails to check his ideas with counter evidence, and he's way, way too fond of story telling. Gladwell absolutely lost me when blabbering on culture issues in piloting planes for over fifty pages. And he becomes plain annoying when suggesting that children should work really hard to achieve success: he uses the example of Botswana bushmen as the complete opposite, but who will be happier? The bushmen who can spend loads of time to dancing, singing and visiting their family and friends, or the ridiculously hardworking Chinese? I'm afraid here Gladwell falls into the trap of equaling success with wealth.And then, in the end, do we get a synthesis of all that has been said? A thorough discussion? No, Gladwell finishes his book by telling the story of his ancestors. I - DON'T - * - CARE!Not recommended.

This is a fantastic book, a must-read for any American. Why Americans? Because it addresses the many criteria that must be in place for someone to become truly successful, and Americans have for too long oversimplified success as a result of simply working hard. It's not true.Sociologists have been studying the statistics of success in business, school, sports, etc. forever. Anyone with a strong sociological background already knows that only an extremely small percentage of what we identify as "success" was the result of hard work. While hard work is often necessary, it is not always necessary, nor is it the only route to success.It is important that people understand this because I think many Americans do work hard, yet do not achieve the level of success they desire. It's not fair for average people with average dreams to feel like failures. They should know that simple hard work is usually not enough.The only problem anyone could have with the book is it is all anecdotal. However, he thoroughly cites the studies he used, so if someone wants to see something more statistical, they can look into the studies, or even better, immerse themselves in basic sociology courses. I think Gladwell kept the book anecdotal to make the book accessible to everyone, which is what it needs to be. Had it been a book of statistical evidence, it would not reach the people it needs to reach.

If I had to use one word to describe this book it would be "opening". If I had two words it would be "eye-opening" and that would make a lot more sense. This is my first Malcolm Gladwell book and I loved it! This book takes the modern classic stories of success and demystifies them. For instance, everyone knows that Bill Gates is a ba-gillioneer success. What must people don't know is that he was also a geek with incredible resources, who happened to be in the right place at the right time. Am I talking a little trash about Bill Gates? Maybe.  What Gladwell effectively does with this book shows how just about any of us are capable of great things, provided that there are enough lucky circumstances which proceeded our birth. Things completely out our control such as: family economic status, technological advantages, cultural revolutions, race, origin of birth, month off birth, and other crazy crap. After reading this book, life as we know it, really reminds me of the game of "Life". Like we're all little pink or blue pieces, and our outcomes are determined by a spin of a stupid plastic wheel. A wheel probably manufactured in china. As you read through this book, you may find yourself having several "ah-ha" moments as I did. I love a book that makes me feel smarter than I really am, and that's what this is. So the next time you feel like an under-achiever, just remember, it's not your fault. It's most likely your grand parents fault!

“I want to convince you that these kinds of personal explanations of success don't work. People don't rise from nothing....It is only by asking where they are from that we can unravel the logic behind who succeeds and who doesn't.” Malcolm Gladwell in his book Outliers: Story of Success goes beyond the apparent way of things! He questions reality of things and takes in account all the things we believe to be part of myths in success and failure.He starts by asking the question is it only luck or genius that guarantees success in this world or is it only hard work. If it is hard work, how much hard work does it require to be actually successful.Dispelling myths and superficial theories he goes to prove the power of opportunities and the right time we actually catch on them! From the point of view of Gladwell which is nothing short of genius itself. The success and failure paradigms are not necessarily genius or hardwork but have impact of cultural legacies also!Once you tread on the journey of reading this masterpiece you will certainly emerge with changed concepts different with ones you started with.To sum it all Gladwell does not accept things are they are he questions reality to the point he gets the real answers we usually fail to notice! Legacies,Geniuses,Hardwork and much more impacts our life daily. This book makes you understand why!

Often when we read about success three things stand out: hard work, perseverance and mastery. In reality things are much more complicated and somewhat random. This book goes deep into the lives of the worlds greatest and brings us an entirely new perspective on what actually triggered success.Two big lessons I got out of the book are:1. Success comes down to many things: time, place, your nationality, environment, family, friends, random luck and available opportunities. However all successful people have 1 thing in common: they are all super hard working people.2. Put yourself in the right place at the right time. If you're prepared but you don't see any opportunity, This means you're not at the right place. Take advantage of the world you live in, every time period will offer different opportunities for success.It never came to my mind how much factors such as opportunity, "luck" and cultural legacy influenced the opportunities we have in life, and after reading this book I feel I'm a lot closer to understanding the keys to success.Overall this is an amazing book, probably the best book on the topic I've reads so far. If you're looking to reverse engineer success and apply the lessons to your life I would highly suggest reading this book.

I don't get this book. Sure there are some inspirational stories, but the way the author draw the conclusion is (in my opinion) very weak. Take the 10,000 hours rule for example. It tells the nice stories of Bill Gates, The Beatles, but how do you conclude that the main reason (or predictor) of their success is that they have 10,000 hours of practices. How about other people who clocked the same hours with the Beatles in Hamburg, but did not become successful? Did the same rule apply to Bill Gates as more recent successful computer entrepeneurs such as Larry Page, Sergey Brin or Mark Zuckerberg? And what's the direction of causality (if there is even any)? Maybe Beatles stayed on until 10,000 hours because they played better and thus got more encouragement?Throughout the book the author follow the same pattern. Throw some inspirational success stories (some which I admit, are decently inspirational) which have some unusual commonality (e.g. computer entrepreneurs being born in a certain decade, lawyers having Jewish backgrounds, and so on), and simplify the story to the point that it appears that these factors are responsible for the success, and make this the lesson of the stories.1-star rating from me.

This book should contain a warning that cautions potential readers to not start reading if he or she has anything important to do over the next 24 hours. This book nearly is impossible to put down and wildly fascinating. It reads like the transcript of a favorite professor's college lecture. Outliers is particularly pertinent to me as I attempt to assess the various criterion which will make my children successful human being. Gladwell offers detailed analysis setting forth why talent and hard work are not enough to guarantee good outcomes. Sometimes seemingly random factors definitively determine wildly divergent outcomes for individuals. One of the more compelling statistics cited was the disproportionate minority of late year birthday students enrolled in college. We have been on the fence as to whether to send my very late summer birthday daughter to kindergarten when she becomes eligible or to wait a year. This statistic corroborates my gut instinct that additional maturity early on can potentially place children on different trajectories. This brief passage is only one of dozens of fascinating analyses offered in the book.

Gladwell tells us that hard work, nurture, culture and luck are key ingredients to success. And that talent or genetics matter much less. It's a pity to find out only now that I could have been a top tennis player, a great violinist or play in a rock band. To be honest, my chances to have been any of those would have been slim. Of course, most ot the observations from the book are true. But they are merely correlations, not full proof explanations. It's easy to take correlations for causality, but we should ask for more evidence before doing so.More, the book starts with a clear scientific fact about hockey leagues and access to sparse resources based on some luck factors, such as the month of birth. But it then goes into various things which do not have clear scientific background including the 10k hours for excellence, rice for skills in mathematics and hard work, IQ explaining intelligence and others.On the other hand, the book is a nice read and there are some interesting facts. It should be treated as a book written for the wide public, putting a lot of bombastic claims together, but with few scientific evidence and with lots of correlation is causation mistakes.

Read this. You will be talking about it to your family & friends for a long time. Many people read only fiction and that is a shame, because Malcolm Gladwell has revolutionized non- fiction writing. His first 2 books were best sellers: "The Tipping Point" and "Blink." I’ve read both and being primarily a fiction reader, I was surprised at how much I enjoyed them. But this third book, in which he explains the story of success, is my favorite.Citing case after fascinating case of successful people & organizations Gladwell’s point becomes unforgettably clear: successful people are often talented, intelligent, and ambitious, yes, but these traits *always* converge with opportunities. These opportunities include cultural environment, where and when a person is born—even their birth month, and luck: being in the right place at the right time. Forget genius. Hard work combined with opportunity is everything. Since he writes so clearly this is a fast and fascinating read, well woth the few hours invested.

This book asks the question, how do you explain success that is so far above the ordinary, it seems to defy explanation? We typically think it is because someone was born with extraordinary talent or is a genius. But Outliers debunks these myths and argues that an outlier's success is a really a product of historical circumstances, cultural legacies, hard work, and unique opportunities. What Malcolm Gladwell does so well is to build a reasonable premise that you buy into, then proceeds to tell you why it is totally wrong. He is a great story teller - he provides interesting insights and the book is never boring. This a great companion to his most recent book, David and Goliath. Both books tell the stories of success, although in different ways. Outliers explains how advantages contribute to success, while David and Goliath explains how disadvantages contribute to success. Taken together, you get the full picture. I would recommend both books, although I am one of the few people out there that found David and Goliath more compelling.

(4.5/5) I like this book, it resonates with my life. My journey so far from lower middle class in small-town India to high tech world of USA - like the author said - is a mix of circumstance/luck, people/life angels, hard work and timing. Just like the story of author's mother.If I could summarize the whole book into one word, it'd be 'karma'. If you are a strong believer in karma and are self-driven, you do not need to read this book. Your future depends on your karma, so work hard and be fair, put in those 10000 hours for a bright future in your field. Your circumstances/luck depend on your past life karma and birth time/place (horoscope), this is the part the scientific/rational world finds it hard to believe. But backed by analysis of few examples like Bill Gates, everyone believes that it happens by chance.Any way, this book is a great read. I'd suggest this to anyone who believes success is only by luck and hard work does not play any role.

Ok, this book has been way overhyped, so much that it kills the novelty in reasoning this book possess.Definitely kudos to Malcolm in trying to give valid reasons to success apart from pedantic passion, and grit-gnawing gumption. I really loved the parts about legacy, which were things we always related to sheer good luck. Moreover, the book has given me a tonne of human factors experiments to go through later.But, the book fails for me in two places - 1. Chronology of stress - the author seemingly reiterates on how lucky successful people were.2. Experimental detail - out of the several experiments mentioned, the author suggested just the conclusions suitable for the point he was making. Some reference to those experiments would have helped.Overall, a great book with something really new and almost-assuring in its content. But read without much hopes. Almost can be said the same about living.

Such a good book! As the title suggests, the book is about the story of success. It talks about real life examples of very successful people, the likes of Bill Gates and various others and explains these stories in a logical way, rather than the romanticised way we usually hear them in. How these people got to where they are, what factors helped them, how the place and time of their birth, their ethnic background and so on, is important to their story. It changed the way I view success and successful people. These are ordinary people who are smart and hardworking and were presented with opportunities and both you and I could be one of them. I think it would be especially enjoyable to those who are interested in social sciences, psychology and culture. Informative, inspiring, well-written, light, and thoroughly enjoyable.

One of those books that you like or not. You'll like it especially if you're a Beatles fan - which i kind of am - or if you're a hockey fan - which I'm not in danger of being. The premise of Outliers is that anyone who wants to acheive in arts or sports has to practice all the time, however gifted he is. Interesting premise which dragged out for too long. The author has no implementation sense and has no humor. Recently I found out that someone has acccepted the mantra that 10 000 hours of practicing his swing will make him a pro golfer. That practicing 10000 hours will make anyone earn his living doing what one likes most is evident in all the average soccer players that abound in England. I didn't need this book to tell me that.

There was so much that was interesting and informative about this book in terms of him dissecting the factors that make for unusual success. All that was much appreciated. Especially the 10,000 hours of work to get to the level of excellence.... something everyone who wants to be proficient at something knows. But he forgot the most important element: You have to LOVE it. Gates didn't just happen to be a 13 yr old with a computer-- it was something that fascinated him. The Beatles obviously loved making music, the hockey players loved the sport. The love for something happens or is incipient in the task and then grows. That is maybe the first stroke of luck. First you love something, then you have a chance to do it, then you spend 10,000 hours.

Outliers is a freaky book indeed. Malcolm brilliantly outlines a set of reasons for why people become successful. Did you always believe that you had to be the smartest of the smartest with an IQ boosting up to the roof in order to find a place in the hierarchical ladder of Success? Think again. According to Gladwell, you only have to be smart "enough"(and of course some other conditions are in play). All Can be summarized in two main words: Opportunities, and Culture. The author explains his reasoning based on people experience and observations (like an freakish economist Lol) .Wanna find more? you differently have to hit the book.It is a freaky book.. indeed.

Such a disappointment. Gladwell doesn't tell you anything you couldn't figure out with five minutes and a bit of common sense. His patronizing tone makes the whole thing just that much worse. Maybe he thought he was writing to four year-olds- they're the only ones who might actually fall for his crap.

So I fought reading this for a long time. No good reason. I just didn't want to. Once I finally buckled down and cracked the cover, it was an interesting read. It turns out that you have to be good at what you want to do and you have to put the time and effort into it in order to excel. But talent and persistence aren't enough. You have to be lucky. Who knew?

Maybe I'm biased because I listen to Malcolm Gladwell's podcast, but this book could have been a single podcast episode. People who are born into favorable circumstances are more likely to achieve success. Um ... yeah? Perhaps this idea was more revolutionary when the book first came out. I did find the chapter on pilots and communication fascinating; it was the highlight of the book for me.

When we think of Bill Gates, or Warren Buffett, or Jeff Bezos , one word that comes to our mind is 'self-made billionaires' . We think that these people withstood all the storms in their life (mostly alone) and conquered each of them. But the author - Malcolm Gladwell tries to broadcast the other side of the story. He asserts that although these people were one of the most hardworking men of all times but such people had one very important phenomenon by their side - Luck. Malcolm quoted that "the tallest oak in the forest is the tallest not just because it grew from the hardest acorn; it is the tallest also because no other trees blocked its sunlight, the soil around it was deep and rich,no rabbit chewed its bark; and no lumberjack cut it down before it matured." And he tried to show that the most successful people are not only the toughest and bravest of people but also the luckiest in many regards.The 1st chapter statistically showed that many great hockey players are those who were born in January, February or March. This is because the cut-off age for all the major leagues(These leagues separate soon to be famous players at the age of 9 or 10) is decided to be the age on 1st January. So suppose a guy was born on 4th Jan 2010 and another on 5th Dec 2010. When they come to trials in 2020. There age would be the age they had on 1st January 2020 i.e both of them would be considered as 9 years old when in fact one of them had a huge head start of 11 months. Few months of extra practice can result in huge differences especially at such an early stage. And these differences can become larger with time because these leagues choose the players who were born in first quarter of the year as they play relatively better. And this is not only limited to hockey but even many other sports.The author maintained that such luck happens for people even in business sector. He takes the case of Bill Joy who co-founded Sun Microsystems. When he started programming , computers were a size of a room and typically it took about a day for them to run a command. But Bill had an advantage. He was in University of Michigan which at the time has first of its kind computers which could run commands at a tremendous pace. And Bill exploited this with his hard work and became one of the best in programming at that time. There were definitely many people just as hardworking as him but they didn't have the advantage that Bill had. He later even said it was like he was playing speed chess while others were playing chess by mail.One important lesson that the book gave me was the '10000 hour rule'. This rule says that one becomes world class and best in a field only when one has given 10000 hours to that field. The author explained this rule with the brilliant examples of The Beatles and Bill Gates.There was a great study in the book which found out that many billionaires from America were born in 1830s and 1840s. This was because in 1860s and 1870s the American economy went through a transformation and industrialization picked up pace. So many hardworking people could benefit from this. Unlike them, people born in 1900s and 1910s were extremely unlucky as they had to spend their prime years during the Great Depression of 1929. There were many similar instances that show that luck definitely plays a huge role in our societies. There was a veracious account of how our parents can shape up our future in the early days of our life. If they encourage us to be independent and understand the importance of learning arts and sports along with school, the children can become lively characters when they grow up.One of the most enriching chapters in the book was 'The Ethnic Theory of Plane Crashes' which explained why some countries had so many plane crashes in the 20th century as compared to others. It all had to do with the culture of these countries. The plane crashes were more common in countries having high Power Distance Index(PDI). These countries are where people recognize a huge difference between a boss and his/her subordinates. There was an instance of a Korean flight which was about to crash but the captain was unaware (He was too exhausted as the flight was over 12 hours). His subordinate realized the reason and figured out that the solution was to keep looking at weather radar. Instead of articulating it to the captain, the subordinate simply said 'Captain, The weather radar has helped us a lot'. What he meant was that it is very important to look at the radar but he just couldn't command his senior and inevitably the flight crashed a few moments later. This is a classic example of countries high on 'Power Distance Index'. Countries like America on other hand have very low PDI. If the flight had an American subordinate he would have instructed his captain to look at the radar as clearly as possible. So the book gave me some really great insights on why some people or some culture achieve so much more than others. It revealed that no one, not even a genius, ever makes it alone. I began looking at people's life stories from many different angles. But I felt that the book became a bit monotonous at the very end. The best stories were present in the 1st half of the book. Despite this fact, I would say that Outliers is a must read for everyone. It doesn't matter if you are a doctor, a businessman or a rock star, you just have to read this book.

I really really really dug this book. One of the things I love about Malcolm Gladwell is that after I read one of his books, I see the world, and myself a little bit differently - a little more compassionately.

Rethinking of success is what this book offers. giving insight to what we call intelligence and how other factors such as your date of birth and your parents' doing and work can effect your success. highly recommended
A little bit too anecdotal and deterministic for my tastes! Didn't like it as much as Tipping Point or Blink
I thought this book made alot of sense!
It was super good and super interesting
It's an eye-opening book. It makes you appreciate successful people and the support from their community. It makes you believe that you also can be successful too.

I would advise being wary of getting over-excited by this book. It is popular social science journalism, distilling the findings of others with just a hint of breathlessness. Yet it still has great value.As with so many compendia of recent research, the data is shoe-horned into a general thesis which probably grossly over-simplifies the facts of the matter. Gladwell is trying to tell us that we have gone too far in believing our own myths about success and that chance and history have far more influence on how we achieve than we think. So far, so well argued.He demonstrates his case very well but he fails utterly to question the social construction of 'success' We have here that odd thing that is quite fashionable now - the questioning of Western ways of doing things without ever really questioning our aims and objectives as Westerners.'Outliers' will please the puzzled and confused progressive liberal looking for a way out of the dilemma posed by the evident failures of a meritocratic and egalitarian ideology.Progressives dug a whole for themselves with 'blank slate' thinking and now find themselves uncomfortable with the rather obvious fact that their society seems to be falling apart and that this threatens their somewhat tenuous hold on things.Needless to say, they cannot question their own core values and so they must - like Hitler in the bunker - blame their charges or - in a less unpleasant but patronising manner - regard their charges as children who require more discipline.The talented do not work hard enough but this is not their fault because of 'society' and 'history' so these wise progressives must intervene and change the circumstances. This is the panicky contemporary drift of a failed bourgeoisie to ensure that its values are not merely imposed on society but that '68 be reversed and old-style authoritarian methods be reintroduced without actually ever admitting failure.In this context, and as so often with 'bourgeois liberals', Gladwell wants his cake and to eat it. He wants the return of old virtues but he wants a progressive society and that's where the shoe-horning comes in.But he is right about two truths - if you want conventional success, there is no substitute for making your luck work for you with intense hard work (his 10,000 hours of practice) and if we want a 'productive society' then we may need to change the luck of the lost talented.But he does not get that his model of 'success' - a neat bourgeois one reflecting the rise of his own black British family - is an ideology and that there may be costs of consequence to the interventions required to change the game of chance in favour of his values.In short, a top-down progressive vision of what is right and proper is based on a particular class stance - the educated minority middle class winner in a progressive socio-political game where it is assumed that what must be achieved is a rise to the top of a hill owned by others.It is a dominant ideology but it is not the only one. It begins to show its true colours in an account of a boot camp of a school in Brooklyn where parents compete, understandably enough, to turn their children into junior mandarins at the expense of play and pleasure.Read this in association with his account of social psychological research into the difference between ambitious middle class parents and working class deference and culture and you are beginning to see what the game is - all must be bourgeois if we are to be equal! We might call this socialism-lite without the real redistributive bits. Milk and water socialism, designed to find the kids with an IQ over 120 and make them work for bourgeois order through effective social 'intervention', making parental ambition work for the social.Can society only develop the undoubtedly lost talent in the working classes by making the working class think like the middle class, using positive discrimination if necessary to drive change, and by removing young kids from their birth culture to the culture of the master class?This now prevalent attitude in the metropolitan Anglo-Saxon middle classes is a sign of panic that the reverse is, in fact, happening - that, in the internet age, the 'virtues' of hard work will be lost and society crumble. What they really fear is a transvaluation of values where 'success' might not quite mean what it has meant since the Protestant revolution and printing was made widespread, that is, a ratcheting up a ladder of property-owning with one's cultural status based on book-learning. The book is riddled with a hidden anxiety. Social psychological 'facts' are drawn into a game where society demands the use of all talents to meet its needs, using the claim that such a demand is in the interests of the individuals concerned. But this claim is dubious.I was one of those 10,000 hour kids through an accident of history and personality and I then spent 30 years unwinding the absurd value system involved. It did me a great deal of good in terms of the forms of society, a great deal of bad in terms of the substance of the person.It should not have to be an either/or - the successful particiopation in the social at the expense of the individual's questioning and searching substance - but that is what we have. To develop an ideology of the social where the individual is defined by the social alone is as absurd as an individualist ideology where society is defined by the individual alone.This book is one of a number of contemporary intellectual marker texts where fears engendered by individualistic baby boomer failures are simply resulting in a lurch to the neo-social right - much as Fabians caused a lurch from the alleged failures of Victorian individualism.The middle classes as narcissistic libertarians or as authoritarian nannies changes nothing in terms of the base line here - a greater population guided by the ideology of the few.The middle classes became rich on the market and, now that it is turning on them, they are frightened of it ... the propensity of any class to create ideologies of power based on particular readings of 'science' is never-ending. Gladwell's account of the Brooklyn School broke my heart as I saw yet another generation of kids, this time minority black, being driven into the state of becoming social automata.This is a world where it is to be regarded as noble and great to become an accountant, a well paid servitor to capital. Or rather - it is enough to rise comparatively ... every worker or minority child who 'rises' also endorses the power of the class they rise into. It matches the equally depressing story of 'genius' Chris Langan which Gladwell correctly interprets as an indictment of social failures by parents and teachers. Gladwell fails to understand fully a magnificent example of triumph not only over adversity but towards creativity.Gladwell rightly points out that a personality aspect of Langan, created by his condition, played a major role in his bad luck but he misses the social policy implications.Instead of driving the brightest from their cultures into a new culture through force-fed education, a higher education would be to work with the population - all the population - on its own ability to understand itself, engage in critical thought and become assertive.Ay, there's the rub. What self-aware bourgeois liberal actually wants a population that is self-aware, critical, questioning and assertive? This is the same liberal elite that is busy cutting deals with obscurantist traditional faiths at home and abroad.Cut under the skin of liberal progressive culture and you find a fundamental and very old-fashioned fear of the 'mob' that has been suppressed under 'Leftist' ideology for half a century but which rises like the fear of Bane in 'The Dark Knight Rises'.Bane is the nightmare of this class - unknowable, effective, intelligent, brutal, vengeful - and the hidden sub-text is the fear of retribution. Social science's purpose today is to manage this monster rising from the deep - which, of course, is a fiction.I may not agree with Langan's account of how intelligent design is possible but it has to be said that I, as a confirmed existentialist materialist, found his account (on the internet) of how it might be conceivable to be the first persuasive account that I have ever come across.In other words for all the negativity in his life and suffering, Langan is his own man and not the creature of another. This is what we should be creating - autonomous, responsible individuals - not automata trained into submissive props for a crumbling order.Langan is a triumph against the odds but I fear that the attempt to help a select group of humanity through what amount to progressivist terror tactics will simply create a sub-nation of fearful sheep, trying to manage an increasingly resentful and not stupid mass.The real way forward simply involves sufficient redistribution of resources and protections to allow the talented to find their own path where they can do their 10,000 hours at what they love. But, er, that would mean cutting into the nest eggs of the middle classes ... oops!Others may choose simply to live and love without inordinate pressure to meet the 'competitive advantage' ideological demands of those who are already winners and fear becoming losers. And why not if they can pay their way through sufficient work. The new social sciences certainly give us important insights - the work of Nisbett on cultural difference and cultural baggage is of the greatest importance if only because it shatters the universalist nonsense on which our liberal friends have relied to date - but they are guidance notes and not commands.The aims of humanity are not and can never be scientific or commanded by social science. When social scientists start offering fixed advice, one must always ask 'for whom' are these commands made - the claim that they are commands for the individual are usually spurious.This is still a very useful book - each chapter is filled with important insights - but it is vital that such books draw us towards independent thought and do not become a substitute for it.

In this book Malcolm Gladwell asks the question: what makes high-achievers different?The myth of talentOur culture tends to attribute an individuals success to his or her talent and abilities, a so called “self-made” individual. It turns out that the “self-made man” is a myth.There are many hidden factors which play an important role in every persons success.The abilities/qualities thresholdOnce a certain level of ability or quality is reached, going beyond that point does not make that much difference in a persons life.Example: Once a basketball player has reached a certain height, having an extra couple of inches would not make that much a difference for the player.The same is true for the IQ of an individual. Over the years there has been done an enormous amount of research to determine whether a person’s performance on IQ tests like the Raven’s test translate to real life success.An IQ score below 70 is considered to be mental disability. A score of 100 is average and probably enough to be able to handle college. For competitive a graduate program meanwhile, you probably will need at least a score of 115.The higher your score, the more education and money you will get and strangely enough, the longer you’ll live. But this correlation is only true up to a point.Once an individual has reached an IQ around 120, having additional IQ points doesn’t seem to produce a measurable real-world advantage.Example: A scientist with an IQ of 130 is as likely to win a Nobel Prize as is one whose IQ is 180.There are people like Chris Langan who have an IQ of 195, that’s 30% more than the 150 points of Einstein’s IQ. But that doesn’t mean that Langan is 30% smarter than Eistein. The IQ threshold means that both are smart enought to reason about really hard things like physics.The 10.000 hours for world-class mastery.Talent is certainly a key ingredient for success but talent alone won’t do it. All world-class performers have invested an enormous amount of time of practice.Example: Bill Gates spent an enormous amount of time learning computer programming.The beatles spent an enormous amount of time on stage before they became world-class.Studies have shown that in order to get to world-class mastery, you need to spend around 10.000 hours of practice. That is a lot of time, it can take a decade to put in that amount of time into practice. Which is why you have to start earlier.But depending on what you do, you’ll also need the equipment necessary to practice. Bill Gates was very lucky to go to a private school called Lakeside in 1968, one of the few schools at that time to open a computer club with a computer terminal.Practical intelligenceSociologist Annette Lareau found that children from wealthier families tend to have more chances for success than children from poorer households. That is because of practical intelligence.Practical intelligence is a procedural knowledge which enables you to change situations to get what you want.In other words, the ability to interact and negotiate with other people including authority figures, to know who to ask what, how and when.Wealthy parents teach their children to customize a situation to suit to their needs. Poorer parents tend to let their children follow the pattern of “natural growth”.This means that children from a poorer background tend to have less practical intelligence.Where you geographically com from, can have an impact on what you achieveThe “Asians are good at math” stereotype actually has some fundament.One reason is language, when children learn the words for numbers in asian languages, they learn to add them up too.Another reason could be the work ethic of rice farming. Farming rice is much harder than farming western crops. It demands precision, coordination and patience.Research has shown that students from western countries give up on math problems far sooner than students in eastern countries do.Recognizing the importance of cultural legacy can helpExample: Korean Air, an airline which had a terrible safety record before the year 2000 corrected its safety by hiring an American firm which helped improve its flight crew’s communication skills.The problem was that the Korean cultural values, which include respecting authority figures in a sense that you should always defer to an individual with higher rank, had become the cause of at least one of many accidents.In one case the flight’s first officer tried to tell the exhausted captain that the visibility was too low to attempt a visual landing. But in order to avoid offending the captain with an explicit command, he merely said, “Don’t you think it rains more, in this area, here?”. The captain of course ignored the officer’s timid comment about the weather and their plane crashed into a hill.The key message of the book: Extraordinary success is often a series of lucky opportunities and a lot of practice.

There is something about the way that Malcolm Gladwell writes that rubs me wrongly. I’ve had to struggle through parts of his books, especially in the earlier stages. I think a large part of the reason for this is that our personal ideologies are very different. So when MG makes a conclusive observation off of a fact it can feel like an attack on something important to me and I don’t initially realize it. Internally I react defensively and can focus on things MG hasn’t accounted for or examples that run contrary to his deduction. I want to believe things based on reasoning and not emotion and it’s very helpful to fight through my resistance. Both “David & Goliath” and “Outliers” have been powerful to experience. I’ve walked away from both books with a different perspective than I entered, and while I don’t think I’ll ever subscribe to Gladwell’s worldview, his work does help me understand and improve my own.Outliers is about understanding unknown or overlooked aspects that enable people to succeed. Gladwell focuses on a handful of elements that are essential and highlights them among a wide range of stories. The stories are powerfully told by themselves and finding the unseen links between them is a heady experience. MG does a good job here of selecting examples from both well known figures and people whose stories could otherwise go unheard. There was one thing that I found disturbing in the final chapter, that I don’t feel comfortable leaving un-commented on. Gladwell tells a personal story from his own ancestry. A grandfather on his maternal line was a slave owner who purchased and owned one of his grandmothers. MG makes a couple of statements in telling this story which disturbed me. He says that some of the sexual “relationships” between the white “masters” and the women who they’ve enslaved were non consensual. Which implies that some of the “relationships” were consensual, which I believe to be impossible. The dynamic that exists in a society where one individual has no rights and is legally the property of and can be beaten, raped or killed by the other individual prevents the ability to consent. At the very end of this chapter MG gives some of the responsibility for the success of his mixed race ancestors to the slave master who impregnated their mother/grandmother. For allowing them to be “colored” instead of black which was an advantage in the oppressed society of the time. That slave master helped to create and/or propagate that abominable society, without him or people like him the descendants of his great grandmother would have been better off. Giving him an credit for rape and oppression seems offensive.

I hate to trash books and give them one star but in this case I simply wanted to call attention to the fact that his overall premise is absurd and lacking. There is a lot of fun to be had reading this book but I wish he had started with the thought that a whole hell of a lot of people have achieved great success with little or no merit. I gave his last book that I read one star so I have to give this book five stars. I think the star rating is sort of retarded in the first place but I play along because that's how the game works here.Once again, I think that Gladwell cherry-picks stories that back up his premise while ignoring perhaps thousands of others that go the other way. There are loads of success stories in which the protagonist had no sort of support, or wasn’t born into the right demographic, or whatever advantage he discusses in this work. There were a lot of really great stories in this book but I don’t think that there is much to take away from this on a personal level. I’ve also never thought that anyone has ever achieved greatness on their own and I resent all of the loudmouths who do.This was the Republicans’ war cry back in 2008. “We built it!” or some stupid shit like that. Or the Sarah Palins of the world who took advantage of everything middle class America offered and then demands tax cuts so they don’t have to fund these things for future generations, stuff like free public education, inexpensive university education, the post office, and lots of other things we took for granted at one time and are now being defunded right and left. I have said that I’ve never seen any prodigies in language learning; everyone I know who is good at languages has also worked their ass off to get there. This is also true in music. There are people with loads of talent, and people like me who have very little natural ability on the piano, but everyone who is a great musician worked like a dog to get there. I liked the part about the feuding hillbillies in Harlan County and their relation to hill people in Sicily and Greece and how this is a result of herding cultures versus farming cultures. I don’t know how true this is but it’s a very interesting concept.Relating Asians proclivity for math because they harvest rice was the biggest stretch in this book and I didn’t really buy it at all. Perhaps Asians are good at math because they are more deferential to authority than Westerners and thus pay attention in class better at an early age.I was discussing this book with a Spanish friend who is VERY conservative, like Franco conservative. He disagreed with every premise of this book and told me that genius is genius and has absolutely nothing to do with environment. I found myself defending the premise of this book only hours after writing this rather scathing review of Outliers.If someone called me an asshole, I might slap them and I’m not from the South, I’m just a guy who doesn’t like to take shit from anybody. Call it honor or not letting someone walk all over you without a fight.Then he goes on in the post book interview to say that a lot of company executives have made a hell of a lot of money with little talent or education. I wish he had pursued this aspect of “success” as assiduously as he sought out his “stories of success.” Most hyper-successful people (hyper-rich) these day are mostly thieves. He goes on to say that all great comedians are either Jewish or black which is just stupid. Steve Martin was perhaps the most successful comedians in recent American history and he wasn’t black or Jewish, although he claimed to be a black child in The Jerk. Being funny is an attention-getting device and people who crave attention come from all walks of life.P.S. I had lots of reasons not to like this book. Starting with a premise and working backwards to prop up your premise by finding examples that reinforce the idea while discarding those that don’t is pretty shoddy pseudo-science. However, I have to admit that I began playing the piano again after reading this book.I first began learning the piano when I was about 40. I knew nothing about music and taught myself how to read music. I took lessons. I practiced. The lessons were expensive but I was making a lot of money at that time. After about five years I stopped playing out of frustration. I just didn’t feel like I was getting any better. I now know that I was getting better, I just wasn’t improving as quickly as I wanted.When I moved to Spain years ago, I already spoke Spanish, or so I thought. When I arrived, I figured that I would be totally fluent in a year (anyone who has really studied languages hates the word “fluent” because it is completely meaningless). After my second year, I thought that I would never learn to speak the language with any sort of skill. After five years, I thought that I was getting somewhere. What I got from this experience was that learning a language takes a lot of hard work, and a lot of time.What I took from Outliers was the idea of the 10,000 hours thing. I thought about my unsuccessful attempt to learn to play the piano. First of all, I did have quite a bit of success and I quit. I also realized that I didn’t practice enough, not because I was lazy or didn’t have the proper motivation, but I simply didn’t know how much I needed to practice to achieve the level I aspired to on the instrument. I have worked extremely hard to learn Spanish. I can say that you won't learn a language simply because you live where the language is spoken. I know many expats here whose Spanish is shit, even after many, many years.I thought about the 10,000 thing and I decided that I would try again with the piano, but this time around I would practice a lot more. Two and half years later (as of 13SEP19) I still suck, but I am happy with my progress with the piano. Thanks to YouTube, I know how to practice as well as how much. I don’t know if I will ever make it to 10,000 hours before I die, but I’ll die trying.

I initially gave this two stars, but I've been kind of stewing over this (I didn't sleep well, thinking about it), and I don't think it merits two. Before I get too far into this, let me say that I thought David and Goliath by Gladwell was one of the better books I've read, and it really shifted my mindset about adversity. If anything, Outliers is the antithesis of David and Goliath, and if not for the anecdotal nature of both, I'd barely believe they were written by the same author.I think this book is irresponsible. The premise for the book is that for most of us, we're average (okay, I'm with you), and then there are outliers, or people who surpass the norm as far as outcomes go (okay, I'm there, too). Gladwell's theory for this is that some people just have the luck of the draw. E.g., Bill Gates was the only teenager with access to a computer at 13 (which gave him an ungodly amount of coding experience before his twenties, which led to his success), most Canadian hockey players are born between January and March (and the junior leagues break up age from January-December, meaning that December babies are littler and get less playing time, ergo, Januarians are better by default), the Beatles had more practice time than your average band (meaning that they practiced a lot to get really good).He also uses the example of some poor kid from Montana who is obscure and, while brilliant, as brilliant as Oppenheimer, totally unsuccessful, and Oppenheimer, who had rich parents and every advantage, was very successful (Thanks, Manhattan Project). Basically, Gladwell tells us that this Montana kid, because he was poor, didn't have the practice exercising his own agency in college, which is why he never finished, and because he's degree-less, he'll never reach the fame of Oppenheimer, who was the exact opposite. Rich kids have parents who encourage them to speak for themselves, and poor kids will never amount to anything because their parents are consumed with feeding and housing them and nothing else.This is to say nothing for differences in personality (i.e., some people just don't want fame and fortune or notice, or whatever, and some just pipe up and stand up for themselves), and it says nothing about character and personal fortitude. As in, if you're poor and disadvantaged, you'll never amount to anything, Bill Clinton, Abraham Lincoln, Katherine Johnson, Billy Bob Thornton, Jay Z, etc., etc., etc. Gladwell even goes so far to say (in the interview post-afterward in the audio version I listened to), that this is meant to refute the American ideal of the 'self-made man.' In fact, none of us are self-made, Gladwell argues. We all stand on the shoulders of those who come before us. Well, of course we do, but some of us are more successful than others. Opportunity plus hard work equals success. Thomas Edison wasn't successful because he had good parents (though he did). He was successful because he refused to quit. He's famous for saying he found 10,000 ways *not* to make a light bulb. That's character. It was his attitude that propelled him to change the world. Likewise, the Wright brothers refused to quit. It was the opportunity plus hard work that brought them to success. Gladwell would have you believe that the Wright brothers owe everything to Kitty Hawk's windy beaches and nothing else. Gladwell does a very interesting bit on cultural influences, which I found fascinating. He discusses how Korean Air was a catastrophe of statistics (i.e., more horrid accidents than any other airline) until they hired a consultant to strip away the cultural constants that were keeping them from success. There's much discussion on the Power Distance Index, whose theory plays deeply into this chapter. It makes perfect sense to me: change your perception (i.e., how frankly you talk to superiors in certain situations), change the outcome. THIS is more akin to David and Goliath than anything else in the book... though he does touch on this again (without calling it character) when he discusses the KIPP charter school in Brooklyn. Again, children succeed because they change their outlook on a certain situation (e.g., more schooling and a different approach yields greater academic results).I think this book is irresponsible because it totally lays the blame of the lack of success on aspects that are out of the individual's control. For example, in the afterward, Gladwell brings it home by discussing his own success and how he owes it to those who came before him (I'm with you here). He discusses his mother's opportunities in Jamaica and how those are the result of the opportunities grasped by his grandmother, his great-great grandmother, etc., all the way until you get to his ancestor who took another great-great (to an Nth) ancestor as a slave and mistress, and because of riots in the 30s, universal suffrage in the mid-1800s, etc., his success all boils down to that, and not to his own doing at all. This is crazy. This is like saying, "Someone built the roads that you drove on to work, so you owe your success to someone else." That's crazy. Yes, the roads exist, yes, we all of us have a story with highs and lows, but what matters, especially in the West, is what you do with the opportunities put in front of you. You are not your progenitors. You are yourself, and your own success might be marginalized (to a point) by the socioeconomic status in which you are born, but it is not (at least in the West) a tarot card that defines your fate. In David and Goliath, Gladwell discusses proverbs for success, and an American one is "From shirtsleeves to shirtsleeves in three generations." Meaning, that it's only there if you work for it. If you take it for granted, it falls away. That's character, not fate.I do not recommend this book unless you're into victim theory for when you're faced with challenges and adversity. I think the unfortunate issue is that this detracts from the awesome truths found in David and Goliath.

Success results from opportunity, or at least, that's what Gladwell claims. I understand the validity of this statement. Opportunity is a necessary component of success. Component. Opportunity does not breed success. Success also stems from hard work, ambition, personality, skill, originality, and communication. Gladwell mentions these aspects briefly, but he does not attribute them nearly as much credit as they deserve.In an individualistic culture such as the United States, it is valuable to look beyond a single person and to their culture, communities, and ultimately opportunities. Gladwell emphasizes this point often...in every chapter actually. I enjoyed the first few chapters, reimagining the way I view success. However, by about chapter four, the book grew redundant. Gladwell basically just restates the same idea in different ways with different examples. I would recommend reading an excerpt from the book, maybe a chapter or two. One or two chapters could change the way you view success, but beyond that, you're just going to get more examples of the exact same idea.

Another winning entry for Gladwell. This time he writes about what makes someone successful; what factors come into play that separates people who work hard but never succeed from those that day. And I have to say I’m thoroughly surprised by some of the finishing.I can ascertain it’s been a rewarding experience when I find myself thinking about a book long after I’ve put it down for the night. Such was the case with this book as I found myself coming back to the two chapters that piqued my interest considerably. It was like finding out a pair of secrets the world (or the Man) kept hidden from me all my life and I was finally let in on the secret.I won’t say I’m an expert in reading Gladwell and dissing out every drop of meaning contained in the pages. But I have to say I feel more educated about how the real world fares, feel more understanding of what exactly these findings mean for society at large. And that’s always a sign for a good book.

It’s a really great read because of its consideration of a great variety of examples that are seemingly unrelated. In doing so, it’s able to make generalisations about the state of the world and the nature of human action that, at first blush, seem rather tempting to accept. Of these arguments, I personally find that some are more convincing than others (for me, at least, his analysis of why Hockey players in Canada and Czechoslovakia tend to be born earlier the year was much more palatable than his analysis of why Asians are better at math because of historical factors). In all, it’s a great book for considering new and seemingly esoteric perspectives and instances, insofar as discernment is applied.

Verdict: Definitely Recommended This is the most interesting and captivating non-fiction I’ve read in a long, long time. It has all the ingredients for a page turner – underlying theme, drama, suspense, narration, relevance and a good explanation. The examples provided are in depth and well researched and the jump from sports to aviation to law to education was so very smooth, damn, he’s a good storyteller. "[We and our success] are the products of history and community, opportunity and legacy. Their success is not exceptional or mysterious. It is grounded in a web of advantages and inheritances, some deserved, some not, some earned and some just plain lucky. – but all critical to making them who they are. "

This is the third book by this author that I've read and out of the three, this one is my favorite so far. This author makes a strong statement in this book about those who are in the right place at the right time, doing the right thing....consistently. The advantages they have that make the stars appear to align in their favor, according to Malcolm Gladwell, makes the difference. I loved the research in this. I liked they way he linked things that sounded random and of no consequence. The last part he talks about his own family and how they got to where they are. Very interesting read. So 4 stars.

A brilliantly written reminder that our successes are due to a confluence of factors, and we could all benefit greatly in remembering the multitude of factors (not to mention helpful allies) that had to fall perfectly in place to lead to them--Therefore gratitude should be our ever present companion.Also a wonderfully articulated demonstration that talent is in large part a result of effort, and sheer hours logged working on ones skills (10,000 to be precise)--Therefore a wonderful reminder to celebrate the hard work which drives so much innovation, and creativity in our world.Overall I feel this book leaves one with a better respect, understanding, and appreciation for humanity as a whole. I highly recommend the read.

I added it to my autism shelf because so many times I have heard.... must be nice you got, your kids are/were not that autistic , how did you do that...Practice daily . A little every day goes a long ways. He has the charts, the hours etc all listed in the book.So, I quit about half way... been there, read that book/news article to me it wasn't new but it may be to others... if there was something new at the end... no longer matters in our house . I am done with Super Autism Mom.

I enjoyed every page of this book and highly recommend it if you would like to combine a bit of biography with analysis an science. I am normally choosing fiction books for my leisure, but this one just exceeded all my expectations. This is the type of book that is written in simple language but sparks thoughts and quite a few “aha!” moments. Also, this is a kind of book that you wish does not finish soon. Enjoy!

Gladwell cranks out 5 star works regularly- all with the same general framework of providing insight the average person would never glean from the ordinary thought process. Although he provides the analysis for matters misunderstood or overlooked, he rarely leaves us with solutions for implementation. He’s the sage that answers us with a question and then waits to see where we will take it.

I normally have a very difficult time getting through non-fiction works, as I feel the writing tends to be tedious to read and I get lost among all the words. However, Gladwell writes as if he’s telling you a story and is more journalistic in his approach than other nonfiction writers. In addition, the idea that success is built upon a variety of factors is a compelling argument.

“The outlier, in the end, is not an outlier at all.”This is a great book in which Gladwell talks about some successful people and the reasons and opportunities they got into in a very easy read and interesting book.

Trying to decide on this. I enjoy the first part of the book, however I did become a bit bored as the principles for the successes achieved by people became repetitive. Lots of facts and figures to digest and I found myself thinking a lot about my family in comparisons. Near the end of the book, he gives his family background which ties it all together.

Incredible, brilliant, exemplary. I will recommend this to everyone for years to come. Malcolm Gladwell has a gift for supporting a thesis. This reads like a novel in many ways while carrying all the supporting data laid out in a seamless and logical pattern. I was totally absorbed by this book from start to finish - his chapter entitled “Rice Patties and Math Tests” shook me to the core. This is an absolute must-read

Gladwell does a good job of demystifying the accepted narrative of talent and success. Provides food for thought and makes you consider the inevitable luck and interdependence that is required for any one person to succeed over their peers. Sometimes a little too statistical and sometimes a little too anecdotal, Gladwell picks his moments in regards to his research and delivery. At times it can feel very set up, but he ultimately supports his argument in a well-rounded manner. Enjoyable and enlightening.

I have read "the tipping point" and "blink" but this is my favorite book of Malcolm Gladwell so far.He is Brilliant. Malcolm delivery of an idea is so simple that he will always take you with him. Never got bored while reading this one.

Great read, couldn't put the book down. A brilliant writer who deconstructs the lives and achievements of the likes of Bill Gates and others and how their environment and culture played a role in their success.

Outliers : The Story of Success is a non fiction book written by Malcolm Gladwell. This book gives us an indication of what makes a person successful, what are the key aspects which contributes to the level of Success. Here Author closely examines the lives of highly Successful personalities and others, such as1) Birth period of Canadian hockey players.2) Life of Bill Gates and Beatles (rock band)3) The story behind the most successful Law FirmAlong with the facts, Gladwell here makes use of mathematical illustrations to back his findings. While reading we will come across the importance of practice, how efficient and continuous practice of 10000 hours helps to gain the desired results.Here the only drawback which I personally found is , he mostly concentrated his research in America, otherwise this book is a good read for those who are more into non fiction."Outliers are those who have been given opportunities and who have had the strength and presence of mind to seize them"

Another fantastic book by Malcolm Gladwell. He makes so many relevant and useful observations. Is success due to luck, hard work, a golden spoon, or something else? Worth reading the book to see why Carnegie, Gates and January born hockey players succeeded.
